content.title: zero... one... two?!
descr: Look at the definition above once more. What would number 2 look like?

content.title: inc
descr: Procure a term that increases given number by 1: inc N x y → x(...N+1 times(y)...).
content.hint: inc N x y → x (N x y).

content.title: Adding numbers
descr: Create a term that takes two numbers and produces their sum.
content.hint: This can be done by applying inc m times to n

content.title: Hello? Is there anybody in there?
descr: Make a term that returns K for 0 and KI for all other numbers.
As often with numbers, you need to find f and x
such that f(f(...f(x)...)) does what you want.

content.title: Space oddity
descr: Create a term that returns K (or equivalent) for odd numbers
and KI for even numbers.
Note that the test suite evaluates the effect of the term and not its composition
(e.g. SK instead of KI is fine).

content.title: Take a little trip back with father Tiresias...
descr: Here you'll have to return the predecessor of a number, or 0 for 0.
This cannot be done by passing just 2 arguments to a number (prove it!),
however, 3 should suffice.

content.title: Half-life
descr: Create a term that takes a number n and returns n/2.
You can of course use dec, is_zero, and recursion,
however, doing the same trick as above will be more efficient,
as Church numeral already have recursion built into them.

content.title: Multiplication
descr: Create a term that takes two numbers and produces their product.

content.title: Power to the people
descr: Create a term that takes two numbers and produces the first number raised to the power of the second.

content.title: His Majesty Factorial
descr: Make a term that takes a number n and returns a product of all numbers from 1 to n.

content.title: Down the rabbit hole
descr: Create a term that takes a number n and returns the nth Fibonacci number.
Note that it might be easier to build n-th pair of Fibonacci numbers first.

content.title: Something in common
descr: Create a term that takes two numbers and returns their greatest common divisor.
This is the first task where true recursion is inevitable.
